awd_titl_txt: Development of Non-Perturbative Approaches to Partial Differential Equations Arising in Physical Applications
awd_abstract_narration:
It is well-recognized that better understanding of nonlinear processes is key to progress in many areas of science and technology, including climate prediction and  development of advanced materials. Theoretical progress in nonlinear sciences depends on advancing the frontiers of theoretical and computational tools of mathematics in complex problems. Computational tools, while generally suitable for nonlinear problems, usually lack mathematical rigor. Mathematical rigor is important in validating the  models used in applications.  Rigorous methods of mathematical analysis are, on the other hand, usually restricted to special, simpler settings. This project seeks to bridge the gap between  mathematics and computer-based approaches  for a class of important applications from mathematical physics and fluid dynamics.

The project focuses on an extensive development and refinement of  rigorous nonperturbative methods discovered by the principal investigators to answer important open questions that arise in mathematical physics and fluid dynamics. The problems include, in particular, the following: (a) stability of regular or blow-up solutions in super-critical partial differential equations, especially in Yang-Mills theory and wave maps; (b) investigation of steady solutions in viscous fingering in nonperturbative regimes with different regularizations, and of their linear and nonlinear stability; and (c) investigation of the stability of oscillating parallel fluid flows of large amplitudes.

por.por_cntn:
Outcomes: The funded project resulted in both in theoretical advances and practical solutions, which change what mathematics can do for other sciences. 

One of the major theoretical outcomes is the solution of a sixty-year- old problem in mathematical physics: determining the convergence domain of spherical harmonic expansions. A problem of paramount importance in geodesy and in measuring the background radiation of the universe, this question generated substantial literature.

The PIs calculated exactly the region of convergence and showed that some of the methods currently used in processing experimental data have to be modified to guarantee their accuracy.   

A question of substantial theoretical and practical significance, and hence the focus of much research, is the reconstruction of functions from a fixed number of terms of a perturbative expansion. In difficult math problems, in quantum mechanics, astronomy and general relativity, quantum field theory, thermodynamics and other areas of research solutions can be obtained only as perturbative expansions.

The PIs made a significant advance over existing methods, by discovering a much more accurate procedure of reconstruction, which they proved to be optimal.

Using it often provides dramatic practical improvements, resulting in twice or more accurate digits.  

 

The PIs solved the equations of the photoelectric effect for arbitrary fields.  These very important equations govern the interaction of light with matter. Before the advent of lasers,the equations were solved via small field approximations. Instead, laser fields may be quite large invalidating the approximations. The only methods available were onerous computer calculations.

The PIs succeeded in providing concrete and practical formulas for this very difficult problem, valid regardless of the intensity of the field.


Wave phenomena are omnipresent in nature, whether they appear as sounds, electromagnetic waves, water waves or gravity waves. How waves disperse in a variable medium has important consequences in many fields. The PIs developed sharp mathematical tools to describe the large time behavior of solution to the wave equation for quite arbitrary media potential, which mimics variability of a medium.

Understanding the behavior of shear flow in a two fluid flow, for instance the flow of air over water in geophysical context, or the flow in a pipe coated with a more viscous fluid, has important scientific and technological consequences. Thin film models reduce the complexity of the equations, but issues remain whether these models faithfully describe the physics. We have proved that a nonlocal thin-film model for a two fluid shear flow has smooth solutions for all time, and therefore, approximations made in developing this model do not break down. We also calculated what solutions look like and how they behave for large time.
